newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: Dalai Lama's Austrian tutor says was in Nazi party.
newsitem.headline: Dalai Lama's Austrian tutor says was in Nazi party.

text.p: Austrian mountaineer Heinrich Harrer, once tutor to the Dalai Lama and now subject of a Hollywood film starring heart-throb Brad Pitt, acknowledged on Wednesday that he was a member of Adolf Hitler's Nazi party.

Harrer, 84, the first to climb the north face of the Eiger, told Austrian state radio he was a member of the National Socialists and accepted an invitation to join the Nazi SS elite as a sports trainer.

Harrer was commenting on an 80-page file from the Berlin state archives, which was published in Thursday's German current affairs magazine Stern and which mentioned an "SS-Oberscharfuehrer Heinrich Harrer".
"I was enlisted in the Styrian SS as a sports teacher...I never actually filled in an application," he told the radio.
Pressed on whether he was a member of the SS, Harrer said: "Yes, obviously I was in it."
An "Oberscharfuehrer" was an equivalent rank of sergeant and did not carry officer status.

Harrer was offered membership of the Nazi party after he attended a ceremony in 1938 in Breslau, now present-day Wroclaw in Poland, where he was congratulated by Austrian-born Adolf Hitler for his successful Eiger expedition before a cheering crowd of 30,000 people, Stern reported.
Stern published a photograph of Harrer with the Nazi dictator. Nazi Germany absorbed Austria into the Third Reich in March, 1938.
Speaking to Austrian news agency APA, Harrer said his SS membership was an unfortunate episode but added that he just had to "grin and bear it".
I don't think I need to stress again that I have a clear conscience," he told APA from his home in Knappenberg in the southern Austrian province of Carinthia.

Harrer, whose best-seller biography will be portrayed in the Hollywood film "Seven Years in Tibet", stressed he was only required to carry out sports duties for the SS and his career was curtailed by mountaineering expeditions.
He also denied eyewitness reports that he tried to plant a swastika flag on the Eiger's summit on his first ascent in 1938.
"That's made up. There was a blizzard, we could hardly keep our eyes open. We were covered (with snow) so just managed to shake hands and then we set off again," Harrer told Austrian radio.
During World War Two, Harrer was imprisoned in India but managed to escape from his prison camp in 1944 and fled to Tibet where he stayed until 1951.

After his arrival in Tibet, he began teaching the 11-year-old Dalai Lama English, mathematics, geography and photography and also organised the building of a dam in the Himalayan kingdom, Stern reported.
He left Tibet in 1951 when Chinese troops marched into the country. The Dalai Lama and his followers fled in 1959 for India after Chinese troops suppressed a revolt in the region.
Harrer's biography, also entitled "Seven Years in Tibet", recounts his experiences in Tibet, particularly as tutor and close friend to the Dalai Lama.
The Hollywood movie, directed by France's Jean-Jacques Annaud, is due to open in the United States in October. It is reported to have cost $60 million to produce.
